Elizabeth Rile Kelley

  1. Home

Elizabeth Kelley

Themes

Greek Life
Family Legacies
Community
Business

Biography

Elizabeth Helen Kelley, born Elizabeth Helen Rile, was an African American student who attended Miami University beginning in the fall of 1928, pursuing a Bachelors of Arts in French and graduating in the spring of 1933. Born September 9th, 1909 to William Alonzo “Lonnie” Rile and Martha Rile, Elizabeth grew up in Union County, Indiana where Lonnie worked the family farm. Lonnie’s father, James M. Rile, had fought in the U.S. Colored Troops regiment of the Union Army during the Civil War and was part of a larger migration of African Americans from Boone County, Kentucky to the Oxford area during the Reconstruction era. The Rile family moved from Union County to Oxford in the 1920s, where Martha became employed as a servant for a private family. Elizabeth’s cousin, Franklin Rile, and his wife, Lucy Rile, were both employed at Miami University as a house man and maid, respectively.

During her years at Miami, Elizabeth became active in the Cosmopolitan Club and the Young Women’s Christian Association, both student organizations that included diverse membership. She was a founding member of the Kappa Sigma Delta Club, an organization formed by a group of Black students in 1929 and the first known African American organization on Miami’s campus. Kappa Sigma Delta petitioned to be recognized by the university as an official fraternity in 1932, but was denied and remained an unofficial organization until Miami recognized them under the name “The Color Students Club” in 1938. She was also involved in Alpha Kappa Alpha— though Miami did not have a chapter of the historically African American sorority at the time, there was an Ivy Leaf Pledge Club on campus beginning in 1931, allowing Miami women interested in joining AKA to become candidates for initiation in surrounding undergraduate chapters. Many of these women, including Elizabeth, were then initiated into AKA through the nearby Omicron chapter at the University of Cincinnati. She and the other Miami AKAs were therefore considered “Stray Greeks”, as they belonged to a group of students whose fraternity or sorority were not represented on Miami’s campus. It was at Miami that Elizabeth met her future husband, Harold B. Kelley, who attended the university from 1932 to 1934. Harold’s father, Earl T. Kelley, made Miami history in 1908 by becoming the first African American student to enroll at the university. Elizabeth and Harold would eventually wed in 1937, settling down together in Richmond, Indiana.

Elizabeth’s life post-Miami would see the birth of her two children, Marilyn and Harold W. In 1947, she and Harold Sr.— along with Elizabeth’s sister Ina and her husband Henry R. Bass— would open the Specialty Record Shop in downtown Richmond. The record store, owned and operated by the Kelleys and the Basses, became the first black owned retail business in the Richmond area to sell to black and white patrons alike. The shelves of the Specialty Record Shop were lined with records representing a variety of artists, genres, and labels, providing a diverse array of music and, in turn, challenging some of the cultural and color barriers that defined popular music at the time. Elizabeth worked alongside her family in various positions over the years, including secretary, advertising person, treasurer, and bookkeeper, before the shop closed its doors in 1980.

As a small business owner, Elizabeth was an active player in the Richmond community. She continued her involvement in the Y.W.C.A. following her years at Miami, serving on the board of directors as chairperson of the World Fellowship Committee in 1959. She was president of the Finley School P.T.A.. Elizabeth was a member of the Women’s Club beginning in 1964. After a natural gas leak in downtown triggered an explosion in downtown Richmond in 1968— killing forty-one people, injuring over 120, destroying fifteen buildings, and damaging 125 more— Elizabeth was one of three women selected to sit on the planning commission for a promenade to be built downtown in honor of the victims. From 1972 to 1976, she was a member of the Women’s Auxiliary of the Richmond Symphony Orchestra.

Elizabeth and Harold Sr. were active in Miami alumni life as well— she attended the 50th anniversary celebration for the class of 1933 in 1985, and they both attended the 1985 Black Alumni Reunion. It was in the 1985 Black Alumni Reunion Record that Elizabeth listed her favorite campus memory as the bond she formed with Frances Helen Mains, the Y.W.C.A. director during Elizabeth’s college years, “who was compassionate and helped me to feel welcome to sit there when I was tired and lonely.”

Elizabeth passed away September 23rd, 1997 at age eighty-eight.

Credits

Written by Laurel Myers, (4, History & American Studies, 2023)
